Mattias Fagerlund wrote:

>
>One method I've looked at a method that was extremely simple, yet 
>produced some astonishing results. ( 
>http://www.ventrella.com/GenePool/gene_pool.html ). It uses a far 
>simpler body model that what we're looking at here, but the method goes 
>something like this; the entire body has a central sine wave, each body 
>part decides what motor action to take from that one sine wave. The body 
>  
>
Supplying a sine wave input or some other type of signal would be very 
easy to do and certainly removes the need for the NN to evolve a 
structure that generates one. I think NaturalMotion are probably doing 
something like this in conjunction with an initial NN that has been 
manually created as a good starting point - that would explain why the 
legs are flailing as they are in generation 0. This would also tie in 
with what Mitchell was saying about the "rigged" physical model - it's 
not rigged as such it's just a simplified/artificial physical model is 
more conducive to evolving a walker.

Also this phrase on the web site...

"implant an appropriate brain structure (usually a neural network), and 
use optimisation techniques (such as artificial evolution) to create the 
desired behaviour."

...suggests that they use a fixed NN structure and 'optimize' (search 
through) the connection weights only.

Anyway all of these "short-cuts" combined makes for very good results in 
a relatively small number of generations.

Colin.
